newsitem.title: ITALY: SOCCER-HODGSON SAYS BLACKBURN CAN COUNT ON HIM.
newsitem.headline: SOCCER-HODGSON SAYS BLACKBURN CAN COUNT ON HIM.

text.p: Inter Milan coach Roy Hodgson, who takes over at Blackburn Rovers at the end of the season, assured the English club on Thursday that he was a man who kept his word.
"I am not Eriksson," he told a news conference when it was pointed out to him that contracts could be broken.

Hodgson was approached by Blackburn after Sampdoria's Swedish coach Sven-Goran Eriksson had signed a contract with the Premier League club previously but then backed out of the agreement, saying he wanted to stay in Italy.
Eriksson has been linked since to Lazio, who sacked Czech coach Zdenek Zeman and are being run for the time being by president Dino Zoff as a stopgap measure.
Zoff has already said he will hand over to another man next season, without anyone being officially named.

Hodgson, the former Swiss national coach who has been at Inter for 16 months, said he had signed a contract with Blackburn last Monday after telling Inter president Massimo Moratti of his intentions on Friday.

"The decision has been taken, I signed the contract last Monday and I will not change my decision, which is a professional one," he said, adding that Moratti had been understanding and had not tried to dissuade him.
Hodgson said that he was "100 percent sure that Blackburn wants me. I cannot say the same for Inter. For that reason I am leaving."
Moratti said on Wednesday that Hodgson had been stung by criticism in Italy.
"He's a man who suffers if he does not succeed, if he fails to have the 100 percent backing of public opinion."
However Hodgson said he could withstand the pressure and that was not the main reason for his departure.
"It would be unfair to say that I'm leaving Inter because of the pressure," he said. "If there's anybody who has demonstrated that he can withstand unfair criticism, its me."
The Englishman, who joins a club at the bottom end of the Premier League, said Blackburn had made him the kind of financial offer that he could not refuse.
Italian newspapers have reported that Moratti wants Real Madrid coach Fabio Capello to replace Hodgson, despite the former AC Milan boss having a contract in Spain until 1999.
Other more likely candidates mentioned by Italian newspoapers are Udinese coach Alberto Zaccheroni, Atalanta's Emiliano Mondonico and Vicenza's Francesco Guidolin.
